labels.analysis: The MCP Server appears to focus on providing tools that enable applications to add personalized greeting capabilities. This suggests it is designed to improve user engagement and create dynamic interactions through customizable greetings. The only tool mentioned, "add," allows deploying a server specifically for greeting functionality.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality revolves around customizable greetings for applications, which aligns with enhancing user engagement and dynamic interactions. This is most closely related to the "Communication Tools" category, as greetings are a form of interaction with users. There is no indication of tools spanning multiple categories, so no secondary labels are needed.

remote_server_response.error: unhandled errors in a TaskGroup (1 sub-exception)

server_info_crawled.name: Greeting
server_info_crawled.author: @akaramanapp/greeting
server_info_crawled.overview: Enhance your applications with personalized greeting capabilities. Easily integrate and customize greetings to improve user engagement and experience. Leverage the power of the Model Context Protocol to create dynamic interactions effortlessly.
server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@akaramanapp/greeting/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
